8.05.text:
Thanks for joining us today
for this very exciting Talks

20.79.text:
My name is Jeremy, and I
lead the Asian Google network

23.40.text: here at our Los Angeles office.

26.13.text:
We promote the professional
development and community

28.89.text:
involvement of our Googlers
and also bring you great events

33.15.text:
So if you'd like to continue
seeing these events,

35.99.text:
please reach out
to me afterwards.

41.26.text:
Just to tell you a
little bit about Kevin.

44.10.text:
Born in Singapore, Kevin Kwan
moved to the United States

49.11.text:
After graduating with degrees
from the University of Houston

53.12.text:
and Parsons School of
Design, Kevin worked for Andy

62.54.text:
company, the legendary
graphic design firm

68.12.text:
In 1999, Kevin establish his
own creative consulting firm

72.98.text:
where he became a highly
sought after producer

75.47.text:
of visual projects for
clients such as the New York

78.35.text:
Times, the Museum of Modern
Art, TED.com, and Oprah Winfrey.

85.28.text:
In 2013, Doubleday published
Kevin's first novel,

92.51.text:
an international
bestseller and has been

101.51.text:
also rose to the top of the best
seller list around the world

106.34.text:
And last week, the final
book in the trilogy,

109.84.text:
"Rich People Problems,"
debuted on the New York Times

118.93.text:
announced they had greenlit
"Crazy Rich Asians"

123.73.text:
and the movie is
now in production.

129.58.text:
that it had acquired rights
to a new scripted drama series

135.97.text:
Now please join me in
welcoming Kevin Kwan.

145.14.text:
KEVIN KWAN: See if this Coke
will slide off or be nice.

149.79.text:
Thanks so much for
being here today.

151.29.text:
I really appreciate
your taking the time out

153.12.text:
during your lunch to come
hear me say a few things.

156.81.text:
It's really a treat to
be here at Google Venice.

160.65.text:
Two years ago I had the honor of
speaking at Google headquarters

163.65.text:
in Mountain View and my mother
happened to be in the Bay Area

167.31.text: at the time visiting a friend.

168.66.text:
So I thought, why don't
I invite her along

174.36.text:
My mom was at the
time, 76 years old.

176.61.text:
And she had just been recently
been given her first iPad ever.

180.54.text:
And her favorite thing
to do was go onto Google

183.45.text:
and look up all the extremely
rare and deadly types of cancer

188.07.text:
So she was excited
to come to Google.

190.17.text:
And before I gave
my talk at Google,

193.32.text:
we were given a
tour of Google HQ.

196.17.text:
Lots of different departments
and divisions and really cool

200.82.text:
And my mom is usually a very
talkative, social person,

204.48.text:
but she was pretty quiet
through the whole tour.

206.70.text:
And I just thought she
was bored out of her mind.

209.97.text:
Then we were taken to
the cafeteria for lunch--

214.05.text:
like the main
cafeteria, you know,

217.74.text: have a open house every Friday.

220.47.text: And my mom's face lit up.

222.87.text:
I could see she was
impressed by the food,

228.06.text:
And then when she found
out that food was free

233.58.text:
And you know, I think she went
to the Indian food station

236.10.text:
a couple of times and shoved
some naan into her handbag

241.14.text: So after lunch I gave my talk.

242.52.text:
And then there was
a book signing.

244.41.text:
And as I sat at the
desk signing books

246.39.text:
for this long line of
people, I could see my mom

249.09.text:
going up and down the
line talking to people.

252.60.text:
And I was thinking,
what on earth

257.97.text:
Like, is she trying to get some
secret Google code or something

261.12.text: Or find out more about cancer?

263.79.text:
And then as the line
shortened, I could hear her.

266.85.text:
And she was saying, to
everyone, excuse me,

271.35.text:
could you find my
son a job here?

276.72.text: Is there something he can do?

282.45.text:
So after we left
Google finally, she

286.20.text:
said to me in the car, ai-yah,
I wish you could get a job here.

291.52.text:
You could use the
gym-- the amazing gym.

296.82.text:
And I will finally,
finally be proud of you.

301.45.text: some of you here can relate.

304.14.text:
So some of you might know that
my first novel, "Crazy Rich

306.56.text:
Asians," is being made into
a movie by Warner Brothers.

309.78.text:
There's been a great deal
of talk and excitement

312.18.text:
because this is the first
romantic comedy ever

315.18.text:
in Hollywood history to
have an Asian male lead,

324.45.text:
It's also the first Hollywood
produced studio movie

327.42.text:
in 26 years to feature
an all Asian cast.

331.50.text:
And actually only
the second movie

333.66.text:
to do that in all of
Hollywood's history.

336.37.text:
So it's pretty incredible
what's happening.

338.96.text:
You know, the movie is being
produced by Nina Jacobson, who

341.42.text:
did the Hunger Games movies
which made eight gazillion

345.33.text:
And John Chu is
directing and he's

347.43.text:
the amazing director of
movies like the Step Up movies

350.98.text:
and, you know, after
"Crazy Rich Asians"

353.08.text:
he's going to do Lin-Manuel
Miranda's "In the Heights."

355.80.text:
he's the super hot director that
brings such an amazing vision

361.04.text:
So naturally from the moment
the film was announced,

363.21.text:
there was so much excitement
about who is going to be cast.

366.18.text:
We found our two
leading ladies early on.

368.52.text:
Constance Woo was the
star fresh off the boat,

371.32.text:
and is going to play
the American born

375.90.text:
And Michelle Yeoh, the legendary
Bond girl who everyone also

379.32.text:
knows as, you know, from
"Crouching Tiger, Hidden

381.63.text:
Dragon," she is going
to be Eleanor Young who

384.54.text:
is the dragon mother-in-law
from hell that

387.78.text:
wants to make Rachel's
life miserable, basically.

390.66.text:
So finding all the
actresses-- because it

392.98.text:
was a huge cast and all these
beautiful actresses playing

396.12.text:
roles like Astrid, and
Araminta, and Peik Lin.

400.18.text:
There were so many amazing
actresses from all across Asia,

402.60.text:
from the US, from
England, and we sort of

406.66.text: Gemma Chan, the star of Humans.

409.32.text:
Awkwafina, who's going to be
in the new "Ocean's Eight."

412.68.text:
Sonoya Mizuno, who really
stole the show in "Ex Machina"

419.79.text:
But when it came
to casting the men,

422.55.text:
especially finding our
leading man, Nicholas Young,

425.46.text:
we had an unbelievably
challenging time.

429.03.text:
There were some wonderful
character actors

432.63.text:
But we suddenly realized that
there are very few actors

435.33.text:
between the ages of
25 and 35 out there

438.33.text:
who can really fulfill that
romantic leading man role.

441.42.text:
You know, who can be the
next Asian Ryan Gosling.

445.77.text:
And finding one who could
do a flawless British accent

449.71.text:
So it surprised all
of us that there

451.71.text:
was such a small
pool of people that

453.21.text: were available and could do it.

455.28.text:
But it really shouldn't
have surprised us.

457.98.text:
John Chu and I really quickly
realized that it's really

463.47.text:
The both of us
grew up in families

465.21.text:
that immigrated from Asia,
so we knew the issues well.

468.45.text:
The simple fact is
that Asian men--

470.52.text:
not just in the US,
but around the world--

472.53.text:
are raised from a
really early age

474.90.text:
to focus on excelling in
the professional realm.

479.35.text:
So to go to the best
schools and work at the most

484.21.text:
So if you're a good looking,
smart, ambitious young Asian

489.40.text:
likely going to be
a doctor, a lawyer,

492.10.text:
or working at Goldman Sachs,
or working here at Google,

497.39.text:
I mean, I can see
probably some of you

498.97.text:
out here that could
have auditioned.

504.88.text:
So that was very
interesting to discover.

508.45.text:
And there is little to no
support for Asian boys growing

514.80.text:
up to ever become actors,
writists, dancers, you know--

520.84.text:
And in fact, I think
telling your Asian parents

522.84.text:
you want to go into
acting is probably

524.42.text:
worse than telling them that
you got your teacher pregnant--

531.57.text:
So this goes back to
my mom and her quest

534.27.text:
for me to work at
someplace like Google.

537.49.text:
Yes, there's a part of her
that's so proud of me that

541.54.text:
she sees on book
shelves at Barnes Noble.

543.81.text:
Or like gets angry at them when
they don't have it in stock.

546.31.text:
But I truly believe she would
be even happier if I called her

550.38.text:
up and told her tomorrow, hey,
I'm going to go to law school.

554.52.text:
That's just the
plain fact of it.

556.83.text:
So for me, leading a creative
life for the past two decades--

559.52.text:
going to journalism school,
going to art school,

562.13.text:
making experimental films
for weird dance companies

566.39.text:
All that has been a
complete act of rebellion.

569.96.text:
Quiet rebellion, but a
rebellion nonetheless.

572.88.text:
And when we found our leading
man for "Crazy Rich Asians,"

575.30.text:
Henry Golding, who is half
Malaysian and half British

578.87.text:
and who has grown up in Malaysia
and now lives in Singapore,

582.44.text:
I realized we had
so much in common

584.78.text:
because he was also a
rebel in his own way.

589.79.text:
He dropped out of
school at age 15

592.31.text:
and went and apprenticed
at a hair salon.

596.36.text:
That was the fun, cool,
creative thing to do.

598.44.text:
And he actually became a
leading hairdresser in London,

601.16.text:
and just last week cut my
hair on the beach in Malaysia.

603.99.text:
So it's really surreal to get
your hair cut by the leading

607.07.text:
man that you've
created in a book,

610.52.text: and now he's cutting your hair.

612.07.text: But it was a great haircut.

613.66.text:
Anyway, at age 23,
he left London and he

620.63.text:
kept saying you should be an
actor, you should an actor.

622.96.text:
So he moved to Asia
to pursue that.

627.23.text:
And then as I began
meeting all the other cast

632.00.text:
Ronnie Chang, who is so
amazing in the Daily Show,

634.98.text:
Remi Hii who is from Marco Polo,
Chris Pang, just to name a few.

639.12.text:
I realize we all
shared similar stories

641.60.text:
of this sort of quiet rebellion
in one way or another.

646.07.text:
So I just got back,
as I said, from being

647.78.text:
on the set of "Crazy
Rich Asians" in Malaysia

649.67.text:
and at first I wasn't
planning to go.

652.10.text:
I mean, there was so much
happening with my book being

656.24.text:
And I didn't want my presence
to really distract the cast

660.83.text:
But one by one, the actors
started contacting me.

664.16.text:
And I would get
texts from Henry,

666.95.text:
Like, you have to be here
to see the production.

669.26.text:
And Chris Pang, who is the star
of Netflix series Marco Polo,

674.21.text:
he said, get your ass on a plane
right now and come to Malaysia.

679.28.text:
Something very special is
happening here right now.

684.69.text:
I went to KL two weeks
ago, and arriving

688.41.text: on the set of the film--

690.55.text:
which was this historic
mansion they found on top of KL

693.12.text:
that they are using to
be Tyersall Park, which

695.88.text: is the mansion for my books--

697.74.text:
it was one of the most surreal
experiences of my life.

700.29.text:
You know, to sort
of see the sets,

702.18.text:
see these settings
I only wrote about,

703.81.text:
and to meet these characters
that were only in my mind,

709.56.text:
It was really amazing
and kind of surreal.

713.92.text:
But the most wonderful thing I
don't think I'll ever forgot,

717.15.text:
was just kind of the
excitement and the look

720.21.text:
of exhilaration in the
eyes of all these actors.

724.33.text:
And I realized-- I mean, I
realized that for most of these

727.82.text:
actors that's assembled here,
the ones especially that

730.07.text:
didn't grow up in Asia, this was
a life changing moment for them

734.42.text:
because for the first time,
these actors and actresses from

737.69.text:
the US, from Canada,
from Australia,

740.45.text:
they were getting
to play roles that

745.17.text:
They weren't playing supporting
roles in white men's movies.

750.73.text:
They weren't Asian mafia
gangsters, or Vietnamese call

753.37.text:
girls, or that
computer geek that

755.44.text:
can hack through the
firewall in three seconds.

758.81.text:
Even if they had
the smallest parts,

760.31.text:
they all felt like they were
being treated like leading men

764.89.text:
That had dedicated assistants
and makeup artists.

766.93.text:
And they, for the first time
ever, they all felt like stars.

772.67.text:
Interestingly enough, I
also met some of the actors

775.43.text:
in the film that
came from Asia--

777.68.text:
you know, the ones from
Singapore, Malaysia, Hong

781.52.text:
And for them, they were
excited to be in the film,

783.62.text:
but it wasn't that
big a deal for them.

787.28.text:
A great movie and part
of, but another movie.

790.43.text:
And one night after
the shoot at wrap,

792.19.text:
a whole group of actors
from all around the world,

796.97.text:
And all the actors began
to share their experiences

799.85.text:
of growing up where they were,
whether it was Melbourne,

802.95.text:
Australia or in the middle
of the country in the US,

807.80.text:
and how they had
all come to acting.

810.89.text:
One Asian-American actor
talked about how incredible

813.15.text:
it was for him to
be in this film

814.52.text:
because for once he wasn't the
token Asian guy, and the only

818.75.text:
Asian guy in the whole
cast of white people.

822.59.text:
And he could finally
play a role where he

827.51.text: And that was huge for him.

830.37.text:
And it was amazing just to
watch the reaction of the Asians

833.37.text: based in Asia, You the actors.

835.02.text:
Because for them,
it was a revelation.

837.81.text:
These people-- actors like
Pierre Png of Singapore--

840.60.text:
he's the Brad Pitt
of Singapore--

842.43.text:
or Carmen Soo, who is like the
Jennifer Aniston of Malaysia--

846.90.text:
they've only acted in
films with other Asians.

849.36.text:
And they're huge stars
in their own country.

851.98.text:
So for them, they really had
no concept of the challenges

856.50.text:
Asians in other
countries face trying

858.57.text: to break into the creative arts.

861.25.text:
And a few of them didn't even
know about the whole Hollywood

866.67.text:
So they were absolutely
floored to discover all this

868.84.text:
and to learn that the movie
has become kind of symbolic

875.24.text:
So I have to confess, I was like
one of those Singapore actors

880.55.text:
When I wrote my first
novel, I was simply

882.32.text:
trying to write a funny book
that my friends could enjoy.

885.65.text:
I never imagined it would ever
be published, first of all.

890.19.text:
We have my amazing
agent in the audience,

891.90.text:
Alexandra Machinist
to thank for that.

896.66.text:
I never imagined it would
make any sort of impact.

899.92.text:
And it didn't really
even hit me until I

902.95.text:
was touring for the
first book in Toronto

905.54.text:
and I met a journalist
who was interviewing me,

907.75.text:
and he told me that he
had first found the book

912.12.text: and was very skeptical of it.

915.30.text:
Is this going to be another
book that offends Asians?

918.10.text: But he decided to read it.

919.87.text:
And he told me he read the book
cover to cover in one night

924.04.text:
and when he was finished,
he started crying.

927.11.text:
And he said, I didn't cry
because of your story.

929.11.text:
I cried because, for the
first time in my life,

931.87.text:
I felt that I had read a
book where I could truly

937.12.text:
I was reading about a guy
that seemed kind of like me,

940.27.text:
who's empowered, who's creative,
who's confident and smart,

943.99.text:
and who doesn't live his
whole life being wrapped up

946.21.text: in the issue of being Asian.

949.32.text:
So I found a really
interesting quote

950.86.text:
from the playwright,
David Henry Hwang.

954.28.text:
And he was talking about
why the top movie stars

956.77.text:
who are of Asian descent who
make it big in Hollywood,

962.46.text:
you know, Jet Li, Jackie
Chan, Chow Yun Fat.

966.37.text:
And he says, why is it that
the most bankable Asians that

969.52.text:
have emerged from this tend
to be foreign born Asians

972.88.text:
as opposed to
American born Asians?

976.05.text:
I think Asians who
grew up in Asia

979.77.text:
as Asians who grew
up in America.

982.44.text:
Since they grew up
not in the minority,

984.73.text:
they had a sense of themselves
that wasn't compromised.

988.65.text:
And that observation for me
was sort of an aha moment.

992.19.text:
I mean, I moved from
Singapore when I was 11

994.45.text:
and I had grown up
in a world where

995.91.text: I was part of the ruling class.

997.89.text:
So I never realized
how much help that was,

1000.53.text:
having that beginning
in Asia that helped me

1004.73.text: when I moved to the US.

1006.17.text:
And I think, really, I
would have never dared

1008.21.text:
write a book called "Crazy Rich
Asians" if I'd grown up here.

1013.18.text:
So I really hope that as
more movies, TV shows, books,

1019.27.text:
into the world featuring
diverse international casts--

1023.83.text:
not just Asians,
but of all races--

1026.35.text:
acting alongside Western actors
on an equal playing field,

1030.16.text:
new generations
of kids will feel

1031.57.text:
empowered to make creative
choices with their lives.

1035.02.text:
You know, to rebel, to
become artists, or writers,

1037.96.text:
or dancers, or go to
film school, or art

1039.94.text:
school, or acting
school, and to be

1042.79.text: able to make their moms proud.

1044.89.text:
Even if, like me, they
can't get a job at Google.

1059.56.text:
JEREMY: Thanks again for
coming to join us today.

1062.72.text: Thank you all in the room here.

1064.63.text:
And we all want to say hi
to our live stream, where

1069.09.text:
AGN is in 10 different offices
across the states here.

1074.97.text:
I'll get you the
numbers afterwards

1076.51.text:
for how many live stream
participants we had.

1079.87.text:
We also have an
online forum where

1084.94.text:
So we have 15 questions
here, 41 votes.

1088.18.text:
So I'm going to ask is
in order of popularity.

1091.12.text:
But definitely we
want to open it up

1092.62.text:
to the audience for any
questions that you all have.

1095.92.text:
We have this very exciting cash
box in the back of the room.

1111.31.text:
So Sage will start tossing
that around in a little bit.

1114.22.text:
But to kick us off, I'll go
ahead and ask a question here.

1117.67.text:
This is from Kelly Bailey
in our New York office.

1125.56.text:
JEREMY: What do you
attribute your book's

1133.69.text:
Were there any conscious
things you considered

1136.24.text:
to appeal to a wider
audience while writing,

1138.91.text:
or was this just a
happy coincidence?

1141.88.text:
P.S., love your
books, smiley face.

1146.74.text:
KEVIN KWAN: I really didn't have
any specific audience in mind

1149.74.text:
when I first wrote
"Crazy Rich Asians."

1151.36.text:
It was really-- I was writing it
for my friends because I would

1154.39.text:
I would come back from Asia
with all these crazy stories

1156.79.text:
about people like that, and they
would be like, write it down.

1159.80.text: Write it down, make it a book.

1161.05.text:
And so I really began it as
a collection of short stories

1163.69.text:
that I would circulate
to friends of mine

1165.49.text:
in New York who
instantly happened

1167.98.text: to be a lot of Europeans and--

1171.01.text:
a lot more white people
than Asians, I have to say.

1174.73.text:
So it never was meant for
an Asian audience, per se.

1178.66.text:
And I just think that what
I found, going to book clubs

1182.53.text:
and really meeting fans
from all over the US

1185.56.text:
who tend to
predominantly be white--

1187.66.text:
you know, I think that's really
80% of my core audience--

1190.75.text:
everyone just wants
fresh new stories.

1192.70.text:
Everyone wants to be transported
to a new place, a new world

1196.42.text:
to discover something new,
and to get lost in a story.

1203.14.text:
It wasn't just the same
old boy meets girl--

1206.34.text:
not to condemn or in
any way through a shade

1212.39.text:
all his characters are beautiful
blonde people that live

1214.72.text: in North Carolina by the beach.

1217.82.text:
People were ready
for something new.

1223.30.text: were the second wave that came.

1226.12.text:
Because at first I think
there was a lot of hesitance.

1229.56.text:
There was suspicion,
like, is this

1231.41.text:
going to portray
us in a bad way?

1233.95.text:
But as the word got out, I think
I was embraced by that audience

1239.26.text: So I'm really thankful for that.

1241.49.text:
And in Asia, it was
a hit from day one.

1244.31.text:
They were ready for it
because they see this world

1250.52.text:
in Rolls Royces, things like
that, and they were like, wow,

1256.46.text:
So it's had this lovely
sort of ripple effect.

1263.56.text:
Should we throw the
foam ball around?

1267.63.text:
Who's our brave first
question in the audience?

1275.76.text:
AUDIENCE: Ready to
catch the cash box?

1277.69.text: KEVIN KWAN: Catch the cash box.

1278.98.text:
You can't ask a question
till you catch the box.

1291.34.text:
I'd love to ask your
questions on that,

2507.93.text:
don't have to describe what
everything Ashford is wearing,

2511.41.text:
And then the notes came
back from my editor.

2513.24.text:
Please describe everything
she's wearing in every scene,

2519.27.text: Like, the fans want to know.

2522.69.text: And so that's what I've done.

2526.41.text:
Interesting story for
you from the movie--

2530.02.text:
John Chu is so dedicated to
getting every detail right,

2533.86.text:
but there was a moment
in the script where

2536.94.text:
a character gives another
character a watch as a present.

2540.81.text:
And so he said to me,
like, would this person

2544.26.text:
get this watch,
this certain brand?

2546.48.text: And I was like, absolutely not.

2550.88.text:
And he's like, so what would
he-- what would he get?

2553.05.text:
I was like, well, you
know, this character

2554.80.text:
would be given probably
an amazing collectible

2556.80.text:
vintage Rolex Paul Newman
Daytona Panda, you know.

2564.30.text:
Like we sort of went,
connect the dots,

2566.96.text:
and an amazing very
generous crazy rich Asian

2570.98.text:
lent us his $500,000 Paul
Newman Panda Daytona.

2576.96.text:
And it was flown around
the world on set,

2581.04.text:
with bodyguards,
in a special box

2585.66.text:
for a scene that lasted
literally, I would say,

2592.86.text:
But that's how much we wanted
to get every detail right.

2597.10.text:
JEREMY: Is that the
watch you have on now?

2602.67.text:
But it's funny, the actors were
like, it was your watch, right?

2609.40.text:
Well, I want to thank Kevin
Kwan for joining us today

2614.43.text:
Let's go ahead and give
him round of applause.

2622.12.text:
KEVIN KWAN: Thanks so much for
spending your lunch time today.

2628.94.text: We'll stick around a little bit.

2631.52.text:
JEREMY: Some of you
have books, so--

2633.02.text:
KEVIN KWAN: --or anything
to sign, I'm here.
